title: coronavirus uk live update
story: PRIME MINISTER Boris Johnson chaired his first press briefing in a month yesterday and promised to share an extensive plan to end the lockdown next week.Mr Johnson - who was at Carrie Symonds side as she gave birth to their son on Wednesday - is delaying paternity leave to help in the battle against coronavirus.The PM said the UK is now past the peak of coronavirus but braced Brits for more weeks of lockdown.Among the criteria to relax lockdown measures is limiting the number of new cases to under , a day, while Professor Chris Whitty revealed fears over a second wave, similar to Germany.It came as the UKs death toll reached , on Friday - an increase of .But on the bright side, over one million people have now recovered from coronavirus worldwide.The results of human vaccine trials are expected to be known by early summer - a crucial step towards ending lockdown restrictions.On testing, Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick said he thinks the Government will hit its ,-a-day coronavirus testing target or be very close.Follow our coronavirus live blog below for all the latest news and updates...The governments daily coronavirus press conference will start shortly at pm.Stay here for all the latest updates. Tributes have flooded in to remember a doctor who tragically died with coronavirus.Dr Furqan Ali Siddiqui, who worked at Wythenshawe Hospital in Manchester, died on Thursday while being treated for Covid-, the health trust said.Tributes have been paid to him by the Association of Pakistani Physicians and Surgeons of UK.A statement on the associations Facebook page said: #Another NHS hero who travelled thousands of miles to contribute made the ultimate sacrice.#A spokesman for Manchester University NHS Foundation Trustsaid: #It is with great sadness that we can announce the death of a member of staff who worked at Wythenshawe Hospital.#Furqan joined MFT in October  and had also undertaken a signicant amount of work at the Royal Manchester Childrens Hospital, which is part of our trust.#Furqan was a valued and much respected member of the team at MFT and will be sadly missed by all those who knew him and worked with him.#In South Africa, an extremely strict five-week lockdown has been eased after causing havoc for the countrys economy. The restrictions even included a ban on buying alcohol and cigarettes, leading to the development of black markets and a % soar in sales of pineapples as drinkers use it to create home brew.There have also been concerns over a lack of PPE for frontline health workers in the country, leading to protests.South Africa currently has Africas highest death toll, with  confirmed fatalities and , infections.The countrys National Treasury also forecasts that the economy will contract .% this year.Care workers in Wales will each receive a £ bonus to reflect their #value# during the coronavirus pandemic.First Minister Mark Drakeford said the payments would be made to around , care home workers and domiciliary care workers across the country. He told the Welsh Governments daily briefing: #This payment is designed to provide some further recognition of the value we attach to everything they are doing.#This group of people, usually women, often not well paid, are providing the invisible scaffolding of services which support both our NHS and our wider society.#The chief executive of Care England, Professor Martin Green, has said that the peak of coronavirus deaths in care homes could possibly be months away.He said: #We are a long way behind, because despite what the Health Secretary says, about us being always regarded as a priority, well clearly we werent.##Clearly we werent at the centre of this pandemic. So I just think the Government needs to understand that,they knew in January we were the high-risk area, and its quite clear from the very start of this that people with long-term and underlying health conditions were the most vulnerable, where every single person in a care home falls into that category, why wasnt the response quicker #Estimating a timescale for the care home peak, he said: #I think it will probably, hopefully, be weeks, but it could potentially be months.#There have been a further  deaths of patients with coronavirus in Northern Ireland, according to the department of health.This brings the total number of deaths in the region to , however the true total is likely to be even higher when deaths in the community are added in.The Premier League are considering keeping match venues secret from the public to prevent fans gathering outside, reports say.All top  clubs are set to vote on whether Project Restart # a plan to resume premier league football this summer- should go ahead on May .But, should the season continue, officials could withhold the location of the venues to prevent supporters heading down en masse, according to The Times.A Facebook page with hundreds of thousands of followers run by conspiracy theorist David Icke has been removed over fears it is spreading dangerous disinformation about the coronavirus.The former footballer has been slammed for claiming that the rollout of G technology is responsible for the coronavirus outbreak, described as #utter rubbish# by the scientic community.The conspiracy theory led to the destruction of a number of mobile phone masts across the country during the lockdown.It comes as medics across the world have called for Icke to be wiped from major social media s, though his veried Twitter account remains active.Lockdown in India, the biggest in the world, has been extended as the country continues to struggle with the coronavirus pandemic.The government in New Delhi today announced that the lockdown measures, affecting some . billion people, will continue for another two weeks at least after May .There are over , cases and , confirmed deaths from the coronavirus in India, though there are fears the true extent of infection may be much higher.But the shutdown has deprived millions of day labourers of income and drastically hit the countrys economy.Over  million people have been unable or expect to be unable to pay at least one bill due to the coronavirus outbreak.New research from Citizens Advice shows that  million have missed or expect to miss a bill that could leave them vulnerable to eviction or bailf enforcement once financial protections from the Treasury end later this Spring.The survey of , people, conducted by Opinium, found that those at risk of the most severe consequences include: A senior government minister has said that councils should feel confident to reopen tips #as soon as possible#. But there are warnings that workers at the tips should have access to PPE in time for the reopening. Local government secretary Robert Jenrick has confirmed that some tips will open over the weekend, but that many councils will do this in a #staged# manner to avoid overcrowding and traffic queues.It comes amid a shocking % rise in fly-tipping in rural communities during the pandemic.Of the  recent deaths,  of the tragic fatalities were patients with no underlying health conditions.The patients were aged between  and  years old, according to NHS England.The UKs coronavirus death toll has risen to at least , after  more deaths were recorded in England today.The grim tally is expected to jump again this evening, when the Government confirms the overall number of UK fatalities in todays daily coronavirus briefing.It brings the total number of deaths recorded in hospitals across England to ,.The figures, announced by NHS England, exclude those who have died in care homes and the wider community, meaning the true figure is likely to be much higher.The rise is smaller than it was yesterday, when  deaths were logged in England.More on that breaking story here.— Lincolnshire Police # stayhomesavelivesMay , A further  people have died after testing positive for coronavirus in Wales, taking the total number of deaths to , Public Health Wales has said. A further  people had tested positive for Covid-, bringing the total number of confirmed cases to ,.Teachers believe school staff should be given personal protective equipmentwhen more pupilsas they say social distancing in schools is #impossible#, a poll suggests. About three in foursay the equipment should be made available to all staff when schools open to more pupils in the future, according to an online survey carried out by education magazine Tes. The poll of more than , school staff across the UK also suggests a similar proportionthink it would be #impossible# to manage social distancing when more pupilsto school. Schools and colleges across the UK closed more than five weeks ago due to the coronavirus outbreak, remaining open only for vulnerable youngsters and the children of key workers.Correspondent Face coverings have a #weak but positive effect# in reducing the spread of coronavirus, Downing Street has concluded, but ministers are still deciding the details of the advice to issue. Boris Johnson suggested that coverings will play a part in his announcement on how the lockdown measures may be eased. The Government had been resisting calls to recommend their use despite Scotlands First Minister Nicola Sturgeon advising the public to use cloth face coverings when in enclosed public spaces. The Prime Ministers official spokesman acknowledged on Friday that the evidence shows they can reduce the spread of the virus from infected iniduals who are not showing symptoms. He said: #The advice we have received based on the science shows a weak but positive effect in reducing transmission of coronavirus from asymptomatic members of the public where social distancing isnt possible.#What ministers need to consider is how best to produce advice for the public on the next steps, and that work is still ongoing.#Millions of low-paid and undervalued workers deserve a #new deal# because of their efforts during the coronavirus crisis, according to a leading union. Usdaw marked International Workers Day on Friday by praising workers including those in retail, manufacturing, distribution and home delivery, who have been working around the clock since the Covid- outbreak. The shopworkers union called for a £ minimum wage for all workers, minimum contracts of  hours per week for everyone who wants it, a ban on zero-hour contracts, and improved sick pay. Paddy Lillis, Usdaws general secretary said: #There must be lasting and fundamental changes to the way society views our lowest paid workers. We need a new deal for the workers.#Too many key workers are low-paid, with insecure hours and few employment rights. They have been undervalued for too long and deserve a new deal.#There could be a #dramatic# change to how GPs see patients in the future, with around half of consultations moving online, a doctors leader has said. Professor Martin Marshall, chairman of the Royal College of GPs, told the Commons Health and Social Care Committee there had been a large uptake in virtual consultations due to Covid-, in part because doctors had been given more sophisticated technology and equipment. He told MPs: #Theres going to be a dramatic change. #So, prior to the pandemic, about % of consultations in general practice were carried out face to face. #Now, according to the data, its about %, I suspect it might even be less than that. #I think the future will be somewhere between where we were and where we are. I dont think that % of consultations have to be carried out face to face before the crisis and I dont think % to % is right either.# Prof Marshall said virtual consultations would not be suitable for all patient needs but about % could be online.Questions over what natural immunity people might develop to coronavirus, and which drugs could help those worst affected could be answered in the next year, an expert advisory group has said. They are among the research priorities highlighted as the most urgent by the Academy of Medical Sciences and the British Society for Immunology, as scientists work around the clock to develop a vaccine and trial medicines amid the pandemic. In a paper published on Friday, the group of  leading immunology experts identied key areas of research into immunity and treatments which they said could be delivered #within - months# provided there is #funding and support for relevant research#. Key areas regarding immunity include establishing what,any, protection is provided by antibodies developed by recovered patients, whether T-cells are involved in generating immunity, and how antibody tests could be safely and reliably used. The paper concludes that the answers to these questions #can help us to understand what herd immunity to this virus may currently exist, or develop within the population#.Wizz Air will resume some flights from Luton airport today, but passengers are required to wear face masks.Flights are due to operate to Budapest, Lisbon and Sofia.Other routes, such as Tenere and Tel Aviv, will resume in the coming weeks, pending travel restrictions.McDonalds has finally confirmed when it’ll be reopening restaurants with  branches to open on May .The fast food giant will be reopening for delivery orders only and with a reduced menu in place.To help keep staff and customers safe, McDonald’s will be installing perspex screens at checkouts and will ask customers to respect social distancing rules.Customers will also be asked to pay for their food with card and contactless payments where possible.More on that breaking story here.Downing Street has declined to contradict President Donald Trumps theory that the coronavirus originated in a Chinese laboratory.The Prime Ministers official spokesman said: #There are clearly questions that need to be answered about the origin and spread of the virus, not least so we can ensure that were best prepared for a future global pandemic, this work will need to be done with our international partners.#A group of infectious disease scientists in the US have predicted the deadly virus is likely to keep spreading for  to  months # until  to  per cent of the population has been infected.A team of infectious disease researchers led by the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policyat the University of Minnesota, used data on past pandemics, and published reports about the medical details of Covid- to make their prediction.They wrote: #Theof the pandemic will likely be  to  months, as herd immunity gradually develops in the human population.#The scientists added that this is because Covid- is a new disease, and no one has any immunity.More on this report here.Urgent cancer referrals across England have dropped by % due to the coronavirus, according to the head of cancer services for the NHS.Dame Cally Palmer, national cancer director for NHS England, said chemotherapy treatments were running at % of normal levels. However, two-week referrals # where GPs send patients with suspected cancer to specialists for further investigation # were down by %.It comes after Cancer Research UK said last week that thousands of people are missing out on cancer diagnoses, in part because people are staying away from hospitals and GP surgeries due to coronavirus fears.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stunning victorian mansion john lewis monty penguin christmas sale
story: The house in Surreys Kingston-Upon-Thames has just been listed by Savills estate agent with an asking price of £.million.The ad, which tells the story of a boy and his lonely penguin, was filmed at the property for  days with the crew even painting the house in John Lewis green.No other homes we used in that years Christmas advert.The Surrey property has had other starring roles, including the Great British Bake Off where the kitchen was used, while other parts of the property were used by Ford for advertising campaigns.The detached home extends across four levels with two living rooms and a kitchen on the ground floor.There are five bedrooms on the first floor and a separate basement.On the top floor is a space that is currently being used as a classroom and has enough tables and chairs to accommodate more than a dozen children.The loft would be ideal space for home-schooling kids during the current lockdown.

title: lockdown time think about freedom
story: LONDON’S Millennium Bridge connecting the busy South Bank with the busier City on Monday, April , .There was not a soul in sight at .pm on my daily Government-sanctioned walk home from the talkRADIO studio.It was the same scene in the once-bustling theatre district of Covent Garden and as I wandered past the usually-heaving Holborn Station on to Fleet Street, where the pubs are now boarded up and there’s an eerie still in the air made more  Days Later-like by the unusually loud seagulls craving food.Our unrivalled capital city, which survived the great fire, the Blitz, the IRA, al-Qaeda and IS, has been temporarily silenced for the greater good.So why is it that any time I switch on the internet or social media I’m bombarded with negativity about how the UK — and London in particular — has failed during lockdown I’ve had it with this untrue, unfair and frankly offensive narrative being spewed by out-of-touch, Government-hating journalists and publicity-hungry Twitter commentators.Their only evidence  Harmless pictures showing families sitting down in the middle of a park enjoying an ice cream, folk going for a bike ride on a sunny day and even police officers gathering to clap for the NHS on Westminster Bridge in a show of national unity.The reality, of course, is that the vast majority of us are respecting the rules, at great personal and financial cost. After days of hysterical commentary about increased car usage, the official slides at the Government briefing this week showed it had actually gone down.Is it any wonder that trust in telly journalists, with their constant gotcha questions of ministers and desire to do down our national effort, is plummeting So let me say this in Britain’s biggest newspaper that has maintained the loyalty of our brilliant army of readers with hysteria-free coverage: We have done so well and all deserve to be applauded for our stoic efforts to flatten the curve.Even at the start of March, nobody could have imagined that the UK would spend six weeks without the Premier League, McDonald’s or nightclubs Let alone losing those joys of our national le at a time when everyone other than key workers had to stay at home.You’ve missed weddings, births, signicant birthdays, important operations and even funerals. That’s why I am so proud of the citizens of this country.Do not let anyone tell you that the UK didn’t take this evil disease seriously. We did. Unquestionably.But that doesn’t mean we should now stay silent and accept a continued loss of our freedom and liberties. Our first goal is achieved: We avoided the NHS being overrun.Demanding answers from our leaders about what’s next and how we reopen our country does not for a single second make you disloyal — it makes you even more of a patriot.THE Greatest Dancer has been axed by the BBC.Which is bad news for star judge Cheryl Tweedy, who doesn’t seem to enjoy the same bankability she did at the height of her X Factor glory days .But good news for Girls Aloud fans like me as every solo flop just makes the reunion even more inevitable.lIn other exciting girl band news, the Spice Girls are in talks to do another world reunion tour.SADIQ KHAN has done so alarm-ingly little to help Londoners during this crisis – no masks, no sanitisers or PPE on public transport – that it might be time for the London Mayor to consider changing his name to Sadiq Can’t.MY love letter to the things I never thought I’d miss living in London . . .ONCE upon a time there lived a celebrity journalist called Omid Scobie.He revelled in the sort of nonsense that used to fill the pages of Star Magazine, one of the UK’s most downmarket celeb titles.For many years, until very recently, Mr Scobie also flogged story after story to popular newspapers about celebs and the royals, including the Mail on Sunday.Nothing wrong with that so far. But I’m just surprised that it’s this fellow hack who notoriously tabloid-hating Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, has picked to write her hagiography, I mean, biography of her “horror” couple of years title: cactus fruit cocktail best hangover cure
story: It was able to halve rates of sickness and reduce headache pain by a third.The cactus fruit cocktail helped the body cleanse itself of booze faster than any other remedy.The researchers also dismissed the idea that dehydration is behind some of the most common symptoms of the morning after the night before.The findings come from a German study in which volunteers gulped down alcohol.Those given a drink containing extracts from cherries, prickly pears or cactus fruit, ginkgo biloba, willow and ginger root had milder hangovers.Polyphenol and flavonoid compounds in the five plant extracts have been linked with curbing the effects of alcohol in experimental studies. But its not clear how.Various natural remedies have been recommended to ease hangover symptoms, but there is as yet no strong scientic evidence for their use.A full English breakfast, a big cup of coffee or even drinking more alcohol - the list of touted hangover cures is forever growing.So the researchers assessed the potential of specic plant extracts, vitamins and minerals, and antioxidant compounds to ease a range of recognised physical and psychological symptoms associated with drinking alcohol.But researcher Professor Bernard Lieb said: “The underlying mechanisms remain to be unravelled.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bq visors shoppers contactless branches reopen
story: BQ has reopened all of its UK branches - and strict new coronavirus measures enforced in the DIY chains stores could spell the future of shopping.Staff now wear visors and are protected by screens around tills, while shoppers must follow a one-way system and can disinfect their trolleys at special anti-bac stations outside branches.Customers can arrive in pairs to browse the aisles - but markings have been laid out on floors to keep people ft away from one another.A specially designed queuing area also ensures customers have space.Shoppers must follow arrows that guide them around the shop floor.Sanitiser wipes are provided for trolley handles outside the stores.Protective perspex screens will keep till workers safe, while customers can only buy items using contactless payments.It comes as businesses around the country begin to reopen under the coronavirus lockdown.Supermarkets have already put into practice social distancing measures to keep staff and customers safe.But its thought high street shops could ban couples and close down changing rooms when restrictions ease.Social distancing guidelines have been published by the British Retail Consortium to help shops when they start to reopen.It says although there isn’t a date for “non-essential” shops to open, they need to be ready with proper preparations in place.Shoppers may need to buy without trying anything on, and will only be able to enter shops alone.Toilets in stores could be put out of use, with regular hand santiser stations dotted around to keep everyone safe.In the BQ branch in Chiswick, London, yesterday, employees manned the entrance to the store and warned customers theyd only be allowed to go inside with a trolley.Inside the store, regular announcements were being made about social distancing.Mo Rad,  who came to buy fixing grout and tiles, told the Daily Mail he suffers from leukaemia.He said: I wasnt nervous at all, even though I really shouldnt be out.But Im having some work done at home and needed to buy this material.BQ have arranged this whole thing very well.You can clean your trolley with sanitiser when you go in and its easy to keep your distance.The DIY store initially closed its doors on March  - but bosses said yesterday that its  stores are now open to the public.It comes days after the chains decision to reopen  stores saw huge queues forming outside shops in Bristol, Watford and Edinburgh.The hardware chain had been named as an essential retailer but was initially operating an online-only service.At the start of the coronavirus shutdown, customers could only order items for home delivery or click and collect from BQ’s website DIY.For click and collect orders, customers were instructed to wait for their items outside the front of closed stores.Since the start of lockdown, a number of high street chains have started reopening branches, including:The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.BQ reopened its first  stores to the public on April .Another  branches opened on April , followed by an additional  stores on April  and another  shops on April .The chains CEO Graham Bell said: “Our highest priority is to keep our colleagues safe at work and our customers safe while shopping.“In all our stores, we have strict social distancing measures in place.“Whether shopping in our stores or online, we continue to ask all our customers to follow the Government’s social distancing guidelines and to shop responsibly only when they need to.”The retailer has temporarily stopped services such as kitchen and bathroom design, paint mixing, timber cutting and key cutting.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.

title: uk firms post lockdown plans
story: UK firms have revealed plans for how they willstaff to work after the lockdown lts.Options to slowly creep back to work after the coronavirus pandemic include staggered shts, isolated working and getting rid of cash.After Boris Johnson revealed yesterday he will have a plan on how the restrictions will end by next week, companies are preparing.It is assumed safety and distancing measures will continue in the workplace eventhe lockdown is lted.And many workforces may see a huge dference in how they interact with colleagues or use office space for months to come.The virus is expected to title: dad finds seven inch chip
story: The -year-old was making chicken and chips for his dinner when the monster dropped out of the packet.He said: “It was absolutely massive. title: eradication coronavirus impossible
story: CHIEF Medical Officer Sir Chris Whitty has said eradication of coronavirus is technically impossible as he warned of a more severe wave in the winter.Professor Whitty warned thatmeasures are not taken, coronavirus cases will spike again, putting an even greater strain on healthcare systems.“Covid- is a very long way from finished and eradication is technically impossible for this disease, Whitty warned in a video conference hosted by Gresham College on Thursday.He advised that the transmission rate – represented by the letter R – must be kept low, or it can have severe repercussions.The number that appears alongside R represents the number of people that would be infected by each person that has the virus.For example,the number of R is kept below one, that would mean each person that becomes infected with the virus would pass it to less than one person on average.If we allow... the R to go above  for any sustained period, it will lead back to exponential growth again, and the risk that many people will get the infection and the health service will be overwhelmed, Whitty said.He continued: “We need to make sure that R does not go back above one. Becausenot, we will go back to a second wave.“It is entirely plausible for a second wave to actually be more severe than the firstit is not mitigated, he added.Whitty said that social distancing measures and other precautions may help prevent a second wave from becoming as severe as it occurs alongside flu and other seasonal illnesses.“It’s not just in Game Of Thrones that winter is always coming – it is also true in every health service. You have to think about winter.“It may be that there’s a seasonal element andso, for most respiratory viruses, they are more likely to be transmitted, there is a higher likely transmission, in the winter.Whitty later added: “The winter is always worse than the summer, spring and autumn for health services. title: thousands animals face starvation indonesian zoo coronavirus
story: ENDANGERED Sumatran tigers and Bornean orangutans are among the thousands of animals facing starvation in Indonesias zoos as keepers can no longer afford to feed them.The animals are only days from having to eat each other as a last resort as coronavirus restrictions on tourism have gutted Southeast Asian zoos.Sixty shuttered animal parks that are home to around , creatures in Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia have been closed since mid-March and most say they have only enough food until the middle of May.Most zoos in the region rely on ticket sales, so when they closed, along with the borders, everything collapsed.Staff who are already hit by slashed wages and working hours are doing everything they can to keep their animals fed, including foraging and giving the zoo their own down wildle that is not endemic to Indonesia.But for wildle endemic to Indonesia, like Sumatran tigers, we must do whatever it takes to save them.Its sad, but at this point we need to start thinking best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Nantakorn Phatnamrob, owner of now-closed Chang Siam Park in Pattaya where tourists used to ride elephants, snap selfies with tiger cubs, and see snapping crocodiles, said: Every private zoo is affectedIn Malaysia, the zoo association has appealed for funds to try and avoid drastic choices about which animals live or die.Chairman of the Malaysian Association of Zoological Parks and Aquaria, Kevin Lazarus, said: If thecontinues to June or July, there will be some problems.But were not at that point yet. Were trying to mitigate so we dont come to that kind of scenario.Southeast Asian zoos have a bad reputation for mistreating animals.A chimpanzee was filmed riding around a Thai zoo on a bicycle spraying antiviral disinfectant in a Hawaiian shirt and face mask.Elephants were also mistreated, starved and stabbed with sharp spikes at the same zoo near Bangkok, dubbed the worlds worst zoo.Footage from  also showed visitors to Bandung zoo, on the Indonesian island of Java, hurling cake, sweets and snacks at emaciated bears in a desperate attempt to feed them.

title: cant catch coronavirus twice faulty tests
story: THOSE who have been infected with coronavirus cant catch it again, scientists say. Experts had feared patients could catch the bug twice - after as many as ten per cent of recovered coronavirus patients in China tested positive again after being discharged from hospital.However, South Korean scientists have now concluded that Covid- patients cannot relapse after recovering from the disease - and blame faulty tests for second positives.This will greatly reassure Governments threatened by the prospect of a never-ending cycle of infection and reinfection.According to South Korea’s central clinical committee for emerging disease control, positive test results on people who had tested negative were the result of “fragments” of the virus lingering in their bodies, but with no power to make them or ill or to infect others.A total of  patients appeared to have become reinfected with the illness - raising fears that mutations in the virus could prevent patients from developing immunity to it, which would complicate the task of finding a vaccine and eliminate the possibility of “herd immunity”.Oh Myoung-don, the head of the committee, said that the later positive results were caused by shortcomings in the polymerase chain reactiontest that detects the virus’s genetic information, or RNA, in samples taken from patients.The test is unable to dferentiate between “live” RNA and harmless traces that can remain in the body of someone who has fully recovered.The committee said in a statement: RNA fragments still can exist in a cell eventhe virus is inactivated.It is more likely that those who tested positive again picked up virus RNA that has already been inactivated.The conclusion is consistent with findings by the Korea Centres for Disease Controlthat seemingly “relapsed” patients were not infectious.Dr Oh said: The respiratory epithelial cell has a half-le of up to three months, and RNA virus in the cell can be detected with PCR testing one to two months after the elimination of the cell.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.He also claimed that coronavirus cannot cause chronic illness by lingering inside the nucleus of human cells.In this respect the virus that causes Covid- is dferent from the HIV and hepatitis B viruses, which can remain dormant and reactivated later.South Korea reported no new cases of local infection yesterday, for the first time since February.There were five new cases, all of them in patients who contracted the virus outside the country, taking the national total to , cases including  deaths.South Koreas trace, test, treat policy is being lauded as one of the worlds best approaches to tackling the virus.Sir Patrick Vallance, the Government’s chief scientic adviser, and Prof Chris Whitty, Boris Johnson’s chief medical adviser, have previously sought to reassure the public about catching coronavirus twice.They claimed those who have had the virus once will develop some immunity - and it is rare to get an infectious disease again.Sir Vallance revealed some people do catch infectious diseases a second time, but that it is rare and he added that there was no evidence to suggest that it would occur with the coronavirus.Meanwhile, Prof Whitty explained that with diseases, eventhere is no long-term immunity, there is normally some short-term immunity.TVs Dr Hilary Jones, said there currently isnt enough evidence to sayyou caught Covid- and recovered whether youd be immune for le, or whether you could you catch it again.He told The Sun: Currently we don’t know enough about this virus to say for sure that you can’t get it twice but it is unlikely.If it turns out to be like seasonal flu it’s possible there might be another round of virus next winter, as we don’t know yet how strong people’s immunity will be.We will know more in the future and soon a test will become available to show whether someone has had the virus and has developed immunity.Meanwhile, British scientists are currently working round the clock on a coronavirus vaccine - and have said they will know by early summerit works.Human trials of the Oxford University jab began last week.The team has struck a deal with pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca for a huge roll-out of the vaccine at cost price.The company has pledged to produce million doses this yearthe trials prove positive.And it has promised to put the UK at the front of the queue for early access to millions of jabs.Sir John Bell, Regius Professor of Medicine at Oxford University, said several hundred volunteers had already been given the experimental injection.He said the team should get a “signal about whether its working by the middle of June”.A successful vaccine is crucial to ending restrictions and le ing to normal.Lead researcher on the Oxford project Professor Sarah Gilbert has previously said she is  per cent confident it will succeed.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - title: rats invade homes sleep gardens during lockdown
story: Terried neighbours described hearing the rodents scratching at their walls at night after the mystery infestation in Llanelli, South Wales.One woman was left traumatised after finding  rats scurrying around in her garden shed.Mum-of-one Michela Ferrano, , said: There was no mistaking what I heard, I couldnt sleep that night after hearing the scratching.Ive spoken to neighbours and its a problem on the whole street.Ive confined my daughter to the living room, I wont go in the garden and after seeing a video of them jump I wont open the windows but I know there are gaps that they can still get through.Frances Anne Klusek, who also lives in the area with her husband, said they were clearing out the garden shed and found  rats.She said: We were moving things about in the shed and then, of course, they darted everywhere, it was disgusting. The weathers been lovely but we havent used the garden.Weve heard them in the walls, I think theyre in the attic and I also found one in the kitchen the other day.Its stopped us sleeping, Ive been waking up at three oclock in the morning and bleaching the house.One of my neighbours found a rat in her garden and got bit by one, you can imagine the anxiety thats caused.Neighbours say they have been in contact with social housing bosses and pest control companies but are yet to find a solution because so many houses are involved.The British Pest Control Associationhas claimed around half of the professionals it had polled since the introduction of the measures had seen an increase in activity, according to Essex Live.BPCA technical officer Natalie Bungay said: Rats, in particular, may be becoming more visible in areas of population.With less footfall across cities and towns, there is less associated food waste being left in bins and on the floor.As a result, rat populations are likely to move further afield to satisfy their need for a food source and this, in turn, is likely to cause more sightings.By nature, rats will also try to avoid humans directly and so, with less of us walking the streets, they may be getting a little bolder and possibly be seen in areas they normally wouldn’t.

title: coronavirus pandemic two years spread
story: THE coronavirus pandemic could last for two more years, top experts are warning. A group of infectious disease scientists in the US have predicted the deadly virus is likely to keep spreading for  to  months - until  to  per cent of the population has been infected.And, writing in a new report, they warned nations to prepare for a worst-case scenario that includes a second big wave of coronavirus infections in the autumn and winter.It comes as the number of cases of coronavirus across the world passed the three million mark - with the death toll standing at over ,.A team of title: are recycling centres tips open
story: RECYCLING centres and rubbish tips were closed as part of the UK-wide coronavirus lockdown.However, some local councils have said they could slowly begin to reopen this week, with social distancing measures in place. Heres everything you need to know.No, the majority of councils closed refuse facilities due to staff absences and to comply with social distancing guidelines as part of lockdown.Parts of the country were left with household waste collection services only.A a spokesperson for the County Councils Network - representative of England’s  county councils - said: “Councils would like to have kept recycling centres open during this period.“However, government guidance was clear that a journey to a household waste recycling centre was not considered essential travel.However,  per cent of bin collections have been continuing to collect recyclable waste during this time.Robert Jenrick, the Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government has asked councils to plan the reopening of tips and recycling centres.Hes asked them to be reopened within the coming weeks, amid worries there has been a rise in fly-tipping since they closed.He said: Our bin men and women have done a fantastic job maintaining the vast majority of collections.“I’m asking councils to plan the organised re-opening of household waste collection sites. I expect this to happen over the coming weeks and will be publishing amended guidance shortly.”Officials are issuing advice to councils to ensure they can safely operate amid the coronavirus pandemic.The Manchester Evening News has said sites in Greater Manchester and Bolton could be open again this weekend, but with certain measures in place - including possibly showing proof of an address.However, Derbyshire County Council said it was unable to say when services would resume.And North Yorkshire County Council said sites will remain closed for public safety and to cut non-essential travel.The Greater Manchester Combined Authority says an odd and even number plate system is in place to reduce the number of vehicles on site, reports the BBC.Hampshire County Council suggested daily cleaning and a reduction in the number of vehicles on-site.Lancashire County Council and Blackburn with Darwen Borough Council have plans to implement an online booking system, where households can choose a slot to drop off their rubbish.Similarly, Wirral Council suggested a one-way system and a reduction of vehicles to just three at a time.Northumberland County Council will also be reducing the number of vehicles and advise people to remain in their cars when queuing.Surrey County Council said fewer types of waste will be accepted.All workers will also require PPE.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ve day 2020 when bank holiday celebrate
story: On May , , victory in Europe was announced, but what exactly is VE Day and how is it celebrated VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day which took place on Tuesday, May , .It was the day on which allied forces announced the surrender of Germany in Europe.It marked the end of Adolf Hitler’s war and sparked celebrations around the world.The day before, at .pm on May , , Germany surrendered.Hitler had committed suicide a week earlier leaving Grand Admiral Donitz of the German army to admit defeat.The Normandy landings in June  proved instrumental in achieving victory for the allies, as did the huge eastern offensives of the USSR.Six years of war that had cost the lives of millions had finally come to a close.In , VE Day falls on a Friday.The May Day bank holiday has been moved in  from May  to May  to mark  years since Nazi Germany surrendered.Before the outbreak of coronavirus, more than , pubs were going to encourage Brits to raise a glass to the fallen heroes.But with lockdown restrictions, all public VE day events have now been cancelled.The May Day bank holiday has only been moved once before, when it was shted from May  to May  to mark  years since VE Day.A crowd of , was packed into Piccadilly Circus waving flags.A national holiday was declared and there was dancing in the street and singing.At pm Prime Minister Winston Churchill broadcast from the War Cabinet Office to tell the nation war was over.It was the same room Neville Chamberlain had announced that the country was at war in .King George VI also spoke to the nation on the radio, paying tribute to those who “laid down their lives” during the war.The Royal Family made eight appearances during the day, waving to crowds on the balcony at Buckingham Palace.The two young princesses - Elizabeth and Margaret – even slipped out of the palace to join the crowds.Some had started the celebrations early and didn’t wait for the official celebrations on May .For those who had lost loved ones it was a bittersweet day and many widows did not take part in the jubilations.In America the day was dedicated to President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who had recently died.President Roosevelt remains the longest-serving president in US history, holding office from  to  and winning an unprecedented four elections.In France huge crowds went to Paris to celebrate.Times were still tough and rationing didn’t officially end until .British and Commonwealth Armed Forces were still fighting in Burma, Singapore and Thailand.It was not until August that Japan surrendered after the US dropped the first two atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.The Second World War came to an end six years and one day after it started on September , , when official surrender documents were signed on the deck of the USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay by the Japanese.The momentous day is still celebrated and remembered by people around Britain each year.The th anniversary of VE Day was marked with a series of events across the UK in .This year the Queen will commemorate the th anniversary with a televised address to the nation.It will be broadcast on the BBC at pm - the exact moment her dad, King George VI gave a radio address  years ago.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. But the Bristol University professor told BBC Newsnight: I think thataposs nonsenseI may be so bold. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Boris Johnson has promised a comprehensive plan on how lockdown restrictions will be eased after declaring the UK is past the peak of the coronavirus outbreak.The Prime Minister said on Thursday he would be producing a road map, a menu of options explaining how to get get the economy moving and children back to school while still suppressing the diseaseaposs spread. But it comes as a new poll found some Brits are to afraid to venture out when the restrictions are lted. The survey for Ipsos MORI showed % would feel uncomfortable going to large public gatherings such as sports or music events, compared with how they felt before the virus. Only % would feel comfortable attending such an event while % would feel not at all comfortable. Some % would also feel uncomfortable using public transport or going to bars and restaurants – and while % would feel comfortable going out to eat and drink, only % would be happy to use public transport to get there.It demonstrates the dficulties facing Boris Johnson in getting the economy restarted as he prepares to outline a lting of some measures next week.The Governmentaposs stay at home message may have been slightly too successful, according to a top statistician. Polling data suggests more than % of Britons would feel uncomfortable carrying out their usual activities - like going to bars or restaurants, or using public transport -the lockdown is eased. Professor Sir David Spiegelhalter, of Cambridge University, told the BBC: Itaposs much harder to frighten to people to stay at home than it is to reassure them they can go out again. Maybe our whole campaign has been,anything, slightly too successful. Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said the Government was “working with businesses, sector by sector, to think through how it would be safe toto those factories or office settings or to construction sites, and how they can observe social distancing guidelines and protect the workforce”. He added: “Those are ways in which we will instil much greater confidence in the future in the workforce.” Hereaposs what we know so far about how lockdown could be lted. We’ll have the details by next week  After weeks of pressure, the PM said last night he would outline a detailed plan for lting restrictions next week. We don’t know what day next week yet. Some reports say the government will use the benchmark Germany did - of the number of new daily infections being lower than , before lockdown measures can be lted. But thereported some ministers want the figure to be much lower - in the hundreds rather than the thousands - after Germany’s infection rate rose after restrictions were eased. At least , people tested positive for the virus on Wednesday - a figure boosted by increased test capacity. But cases in the community are still not being tested - so the figure is likely to be much higher. Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick told Sky News that the country now needed to build some head room between the rate of infectionand one before lockdown measures could be eased. The R [value] is still below one but we need to build some head room, there isnapost an exact figure as to where the R is - itaposs somewhere, the chief medical officer tells us, between . and ., he said. We want to bring R down further than it is today and that matters so that the NHS has sufficient capacity, so that when we do start to ease the lockdown, thereaposs some space, some room, for manoeuvre. He added that the Government approach was a cautious easing over time so that such headroom for the NHS could be maintained and protected. Outdoor jobs and leisure activities could be allowed first  Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said this morning that because the transmission rate of the virus outdoors is lower than it is indoors, there’s “more scope” for some jobs and activities to be OK. He said: “Weaposve been working across government, my own department, the department for Business, the Treasury and of course the Department for Education, to think about the kind of steps that employers will need to take to make their workplaces safe so that people can socially distance in dferent settings, whether thataposs factories or in offices. “The dference between indoor settings and outdoor ones - because we know that the rate of transmission outdoors is much lower, so thereaposs more scope for people ing to work on building sites for example, or more outdoor leisure activities than is likely to be the case for indoor ones.” No decision has been taken on face covering in public - despite what the PM said last night  The government hasnapost yet decided whether to require people to cover their face in public - despite the PM suggesting it at last nightaposs press conference. If face coverings are required, they wonapost be aposmasks. The government doesnapost want to cause a shortage in personal protective equipment that should be available to the NHS. But coverings like a scarf could be recommended.Weaposre expecting guidance next week on what kind of material you can make such a covering from.Mr Jenrick said there was evidence of a “modest” health advantage to wearing face coverings, but not a great one. But he said it might give people “confidence” when they’re asked toto work or using public transport. He told LBC Radio: “Obviously we don’t want to overstate that or make people more cavalier as we’ve seen in some cases where in the world. “It’s a marginal dference but it may be helpful to encourage people to go about their business when we’re able to ease those parts of le and encourage people back into the workplace.” The government doesn’t want to lt lockdowns in dferent places at dferent times - but it might The Communities Secretary steered away from the idea that dferent regions could see lockdown lted at dferent times, based on what the infection rate is in that area. But he said it was a possibility to manage the spread of the infection further down the line. Mr Jenrick said: “When we brought in the measures originally we brought them in across the whole country, and we thought that was the right thing to do for fairness and this was a national endeavour and we didn’t want to set one part of the country against another. “But as we bring forward testing, tracking and tracing we will certainly have to consider thatthe rate of transmission starts to rise in one part of the country, would it be appropriate to bring in certain measures or ease measures in that part of the country and not in others. “I think it’s not something that’s being actively considered, but it’s a possibilitythat’s a good way of managing this in the future.” The contact tracing app should be available by the middle of May  One major tool to manage infection rates and lt lockdown measures is to introduce ‘contact tracing’. Contact tracing involves tracking down as many people as possible who have come into contact with a person confirmed to have caught Covid-. The government expects the app to be available by the middle of May. And itaposs understood the app will be trialled first on the Isle of Wight.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe government has issued its latest advice on activities that can and cannot be done on lockdown. It comes after Englandaposs Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty has warned the country was nowhere near the end of the pandemic.While in an address to the nation yesterday, Boris Johnson said he was looking at a menu of options in terms of leading the UK out of lockdown.The Prime Minister said the UK had overcome the peak of the virus - an official spokesman did not deny the possibility of lockdown continuing until June. Asked on Thursdayit would, he replied: “I think we will have to wait for the review to take place and I don’t think it’s wise for me to preempt that. “What you’ve obviously heard from [Chief Medical Officer] Chris Whitty is that this is a disease that’s going to be around for a signicant amount of time. “He said we have to be realistic, we’re going to have to do a lot of things for a long period of time.” With the lockdown set to continue, hereaposs some key questions answered about what you can and cannot do:Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereWhen can you leave home  The government advice for leaving home as remained the same for a number of weeks. You should only leave home to shop for basic necessities like food and medicine. You can leave home for one form of exercise a day, such as a walk, run or cycle - an these can be done alone or with members of your household. You can leave home to donate blood, avoid injury or illness, escape risk or harm at home or to provide help to a vulnerable person. You can travel to work but onlyyou cannot work from home. You are also permitted to leave home to walk your dog   Can you go to the dentist, my GP or another medical appointment  You can leave home for medical appointments. GP practices might postpone non-urgent health checks and routine appointments. If you are not a critical worker but cannot work from home f you cannot work from home then you can still travel to work. This is consistent with the Chief Medical Officer’s advice. Critical workers are those who can still take their children to school or childcare. This critical worker definition does not affect whether or not you can travel to work –you are not a critical worker, you may still travel to work provided you cannot work from home. Anyone who has symptoms or is in a household where someone has symptoms should not leave their house to go to work and should self-isolate. Verication to prove you need to go to work is not required.  Can you safely visit elderly relatives  In general terms, you should not visit any family members who do notlive with you at home. Where relatives who are elderly or vulnerable are concerned, you may leave home to help deliver provisions or medication.  If you are a regular, formal carer, you may continue to help them as you usually dothat care is essential for their normal daily living. Can you help a vulnerable person You can go out to care for or help a vulnerable person, or to provide other voluntary or charitable services, however you should not do soyou have coronavirus symptoms, however mild.Wherever possible, you should minimise your time away from home, stay at least two metres away from others, and wash your hands for at least  seconds. If you have worries about being made to work by your boss  Employers must make all efforts to help people to work from home where possible. In some circumstances this may be impossible – this would apply to those working for a business or organisation that the government has not required to close and requires them to travel and be at work, such as train or bus drivers, construction workers or those in manufacturing, restaurant workers handling deliveries, or those on the frontline like NHS workers.If iniduals need advice they should approach  ACAS  where they can get impartial advice about in-work disputes. Can you go to workyou are a nanny  If you provide paid-for childcare in a child’s home, you can go to your place of work - this is in line with Government guidance that you can travel to workworking from home However,you or someone in your own home has symptoms, you should not go to work, but self-isolate for seven days and others in your house should self-isolate for  days. You should not work in any household which is isolating and you should wash your hands more often than usual, for  seconds. Can you move house  The government strongly advises against moving house - however the law does permit people to move home.  Can you go to the park  You can still go to the park for outdoor exercise once a day but only alone or with members of your household, not in groups. Communal places within parks such as sports courts, playgrounds and outdoor gyms have been closed to protect everyone’s health. We ask that households use parks responsibly and keep two metres apart from others at all times. Unless you are with members of your household, you must not gather in groups of more than two people in public spaces like parks. The police have the powers to disperse gatherings and issue finesnecessary.  Can you drive to a national park or green space  The government advises against driving anywhere for the purpose of exercise and says people should stay close to the rhomes. However,you live in an area where it’s dficult to stay two metres apart when exercising, you can travel to a more open space to do so – but you should only do thisabsolutely necessary If you have a disability and it is easier for you to travel to a more open space to exercise, this is permitted. There is no time limit on being outdoors, however you should spend as short a time away from your home as possible. Once you have undertaken exercise, you should go home immediately and not linger in public spaces or take a rest, unless absolutely necessary for health reasons.

The two sides of the busy motorway, which links Liverpool, Manchester and Leeds, separate just before the farm house comes into view, snaking around the property before merging together again a few miles further on. For decades, urban myths have surrounded the white washed building that makes up Stott Hall Farm and the fields around it. The motorway was built in the s and rumour has it that the farmer it belonged to, Ken Wild, had refused to sell it when plans for the six-lane carriage way were approved. It is believed that planners had to come up with way round the problem and decided to simply build the road round it. Ken had been living there with his we, Beth, and their flock of sheep. But rather than being a rebel who was taking a stand against a huge new motorway, it seems that Ken was nothing of the sort. A documentary, filmed almost  years after the motorway was completed, has revealed the truth about why the farm is in the middle of a motorway. Filmed in  and released a few years ago by the British Film Institute , Cleggaposs People explains why the road could never have been built on the farm. Journalist Michael Clegg explains: A geological fault beneath the farmhouse meant it was more practical for engineers to leave it rather than blast through and destroy it. Outside the noise is relentless but inside it’s as peaceful and cosy as any farmhouse. Ken and his we Beth had moved into the farmhouse in  and always insisted the motorway didnapost bother them. Although Beth did admit it made cleaning harder as the sheer number of cars speeding by meant it could get very dusty. Heartbreakingly though, the couple did witness a few fatal crashes while they were living on the farm. But the nearest they came to disaster was .am one morning when a ft lorry ended up overturned in their yard. Beth explained: “The driver climbed out through the windscreen. He wasn’t hurt at all. Eleven years ago, Jill Falkingham bought the house along with her husband Phil, and the couple moved in with their son, John-William.  They completely renovated the home, which dates back to , and Jill has always insisted itaposs no dferent to living anywhere .“Traffic is very close,” she told  the Manchester Evening News  . “But it’s always windy here, which takes the pollution away. Students from the University of Huddersfield took soil and air samples and actually pollution is surprisingly low.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFive skin conditions associated with coronavirus have been identied by dermatologists, according to a new study. The research, carried out on  patients in Spain, aimed to build a picture of how the disease might manest in skin symptoms. Through the Spanish Academy of Dermatology, all Spanish dermatologists were asked to help identy patients who had an unexplained skin eruption in the last two weeks and who had suspected or confirmed Covid-. A standardised questionnaire was used and photos taken of skin conditions to detect patterns of the virusaposs potential effect on the skin. Authors of the study, published in the British Journal of Dermatology, said that in some cases it was hard to tellskin conditions were directly caused by coronavirus or indicated complications. As a result, the public is being urged not to try to self-diagnose Covid- based on skin symptoms, because rashes and lesions are common and hard to dferentiate without medical expertise. Chilblain-like symptoms The study found that in % of its cases chilblain-like symptoms were identied. Described as acral areas of erythema-edema with some vesicles or pustules, these lesions affect the hands and feet and may resemble the small, itchy swellings of chilblains. They are small red or purple spots caused by bleeding under the skin and usually asymmetrical in appearance, the study said. The symptoms were associated with younger patients, lasted for an average of . days, appeared later in the course of Covid- and were associated with less severe cases of the disease. Vesicular eruptions In % of cases, dermatologists identied vesicular eruptions, described as outbreaks of small blisters, commonly itchy, that appeared on the trunk of the body. These could also affect peopleaposs limbs, may be filled with blood, and could become larger or more spread out. They were associated with middle-aged patients, lasted on average . days, appeared more commonly before other symptoms and were associated with intermediate severity of the disease. Urticarial lesions A third condition, identied in % of cases, was named as urticarial lesions, which consist of pink or white raised areas of skin resembling a nettle rash. Known as wheals, these are usually itchy and can be spread across the body, including in a few cases on the palms of hands.  Maculopapules Among % of cases other maculopapules were identied - small, flat and raised red bumps. In some cases these were distributed round hair follicles and had ying degrees of scaling. The study said the appearance was likened to pityriasis rosea, a common skin condition. Blood spots under the skin might also be present, either as spots or dots or on larger areas. Urticarial lesions were found to last an average of . days, while a maculopapular condition lasted on average . days. They usually appeared at the same time as other Covid- symptoms, were associated with more severe Covid- cases, and itching was very common.  Researchers noted that maculopapules and urticarial lesions are common and can have many causes, meaning they may not be a helpful aide for diagnosing Covid-. Livedo or necrosis A fth category of conditions, Livedo or necrosis, was identied by dermatologists in % of cases. Livedo occurs where circulation in the blood vessels of the skin is impaired, causing it to take on a blotchy red or blue appearance with a net-like pattern. Necrosis describes the premature death of skin tissue.

Satellite images show a train parked at the leadership station in the coastal resort of Wonsan for more than a week - suggesting that Kim may be at his luxury compound - but North Korea watchers have cautioned that it could be a ersion tactic. Kim Jong-un, believed to be aged , was groomed to become the countryaposs next leader as his fatheraposs health failed. title: dundee fc tele player year
story: Season   ended up a campaign of what might-have-been for James McPake’s Dundee after the coronavirus pandemic struck just as the Dark Blues were hitting their stride.The form side in the Championship when the virus forced football into shutdown, the Dens Park club were fancying their chances of having a real go at the Premiership play-offs.However, the season has been brought to a close with Dundee in third place after a mixed bag of high points, low points and very low points.Each week Tele Sport writers have handed out player ratings for the Dark Blues. Despite the campaign finishing nine matches short, we are delighted to announce the   Tele Sport Player of the Year for Dundee.The votes have been cast, averages for players having started  games vied up and there are no worries about emails turning up or not.The   Tele Sport Player of the Year is Paul McGowan for the second year running.After a very strong start, the midfielder’s influence grew throughout the season as the team got to grips with the Championship challenge. As ever, McGowan rarely fell below a seven out of  rating, finishing the season off with an eight after a wonderful assist for Kane Hemmings against Ayr, as well as key displays against Partick and an earlier showing against the Honest Men. After six years at the club, ‘Gowser’ is still going strong in dark blue.Fans favourite, Hemmings, ran McGowan very close with a strong run of form since the middle of December, breaking the -goal barrier in the final match against Ayr. Impressive showings in wins over Dunfermline and Partick in December stand out but his top display came back in October at a chilly Alloa, where the only disappointment was when he fluffed a chance to seal a hat-trick late on.The -year-old was a real star for manager James McPake after he gave him a regular run in the first team at the beginning of the campaign. Such a steady and unflustered player in the middle of the park, Robertson allowed the more experienced players to shine alongside him. That’s not stopped the teenager picking up regular good grades, in particular a fine showing against Dundee United at Tannadice in December.The first signing of the season, former Partick and Ayr winger, McDaid, showed dferent sides to his game last term. When the team struggled to create goalscoring opportunities early on, McDaid was still a regular threat and he’s shown his defensive capabilities more recently as a wing-back. His tackling in the area in derbies may need some work but McDaid will be determined that the best is yet to come from him in dark blue.Undoubtedly a class act in the middle of the park, Scotland international Dorrans showed glimpses of his best form throughout the campaign as he worked himself back to full fitness following y injury issues. The ex-Rangers man grabbed a vital goal at Tannadice in the - derby draw in December and was a driving force throughout.It seems defenders didn’t fare too well in   but make up almost the rest of the top .Honourable mentions go to Jordan McGhee ., Jordon Forster ., Jack Hamilton ., Shaun Byrne . and Jordan Marshall ..

title: dundee united kids light up premiership gordon forrest
story: Gordon Forrest has backed Dundee United’s young stars to shine in the Premiership.The Tangerines assistant boss has been hugely impressed with the quality of United’s academy prospects this season.Several have played their part in the Tannadice club’s Championship title-winning campaign.Louis Appere has been the headliner, with Scotland Under- recognition his reward for a stunning debut campaign.Others have made their presence felt in Robbie Neilson’s first team too.But Forrest expects United’s kids to move even further to the fore once United get started in the top flight.He said: “The owners have invested heavily in the academy and the focus will stay on bringing young players through.“We have a few who broke through last season, Louis Appere springs to mind # he had a very good season and got a Scotland U call up.“Declan Glass went out on loan in the first half of the season then played his part when he came back.“And Chris Mochrie too, he’s only sixteen but he got minutes and has a good future ahead of him.“There are others bubbling away in the background too, in that  or -year-old age group, that we think a lot of.“We certainly have a few players who will be there or thereabouts.”When United’s youngsters will get their chance to impress remains to be seen.With no decision yet made on how to conclude the current Premiership season, it’s a waiting game for the Tangerines.Players and staff alike have been placed on furlough leave, with only a few senior workers left in post to run the club through lockdown.It all adds up to a strange way to celebrate winning promotion after four years in the Championship.It’s mission accomplished for United, yet without the certainty of knowing when next season will begin, everything feels strangely unfinished.But as desperate as everyone at Tannadice is to know what’s going to happen next, Forrest insists safety is paramount for players, staff and fans ahead of anyto action.“You could see the way it was heading over the last few weeks,” said the United number two.“There were a lot of s and buts regarding the season starting again and we had a few plans in place depending on what happened.“But once we went on furlough that brings a lot to a halt and you’re looking at the media, the government and the health services.“I think that’s when we realised how distant things were getting – and that was before the vote took place.“We don’t look like we’ll be back training as a group any time soon and the talk now is about fans being able to come to games.“So it’s about the safety aspect now, that’s what’s going to be behind football starting up again.“All we can do is wait for the authorities to make a decision and then plan from there.”

title: george cran dundee fc email another stalemate
story: I have a sneaking suspicion Scottish football is heading for another stalemate in the next couple of weeks over reconstruction.We’re all only just getting over the last one, induced by a combination of an over-active email spam folder, John Nelms doing his best Machiavellian impression and some shoddy governance.I have to admit, I’ve never envied the job Neil Doncaster has to do as chief executive of the SPFL – trying to corral  dferent voices into making a sensible decision while acting as a punchbag for all the critics to lay into the dys of our game.I’m not saying he’s blameless but his job does seem to me to consist of taking the blame for everything, whether he has anything to do with it or not.Now Ann Budge of Hearts and Les Gray of Hamilton seem to be enjoying that role as chairs of the reconstruction ‘task force’.Already dissenters are amassing and they’ve not even laid out what possible plans there might be to choose from.I’ve been very much in favour of league reconstruction for a long time now. In my ideal world we’d have at least a -team top flight. I’ve already given up hope of the Premiership clubs agreeing to another other than , however. Sorry, Dundee.My thinking is Nelms’ play over the vote saga was to force reconstruction into happening – I don’t think it’s going to benefit the Dark Blues in the immediate future, however.Next season they should be big favourites in the second tier, though. And a bigger top flight makes it easier to stay up the following season, too.Dundee United, on the other hand, can sit back safe in the knowledge they are a Premiership club no matter what – as long as it’s not a reduced ision, they’ll be happy.A stalemate, though, is brewing, I reckon.Already Budge and Gray have talked up dferent approaches – Hearts want a temporary change while Accies want permanent.Temporary seems pretty pointless to me – that only benefits a handful of clubs, one of them being Hearts. The rest will no doubt shout that down.Now, though, the League Two teams are ganging up on the rest.I have to admire the bolshiness of that, to be honest.They want a -- set-up or nothing. I quite like that idea.Bigger leagues make things more interesting and improve our football.Already, though, clubs higher up the food chain are taking potshots at them.I can’t help but think these are only opening salvos in another departure from sanity from Scottish football.Dundee United are talking of aiming high – that’s exactly what they should be doing.Managing director Mal Brannigan says the club should be targeting the top six and, beyond that,Normally I’d think the manager of a newly-promoted club whose top director had mentioned Europe and trophies would be thinking: #Thanks very much for making my job harder.#However, Robbie Neilson has the same targets at Tannadice and spoke about European football months ago.I like a club to be ambitious and United have enough about them as a club to be a top-six power again.That’s where they were when I moved to Dundee and it didn’t seem like they were punching above their weight.Right now, though, they are far from that level.Fans will like the big talk and they should definitely be allowed to dream.Backing up those words is the hard part, though. I sincerely hope the top dogs at United can do just that –they do, it’ll be some ride at Tannadice.ARSENAL have begun training again and the English Premier League have launched ‘Project Restart’.With England – and particularly London – hit worse by the coronavirus than we are up here, I find it strange to see clubs and leagues ing back into things so quickly.I desperately want to see football back as soon as possible but there needs to be awareness that it looks like one rule for rich footballers and another for the rest of us.FIFA are talking about allowing five subs per team to ease congestion when the game kicks off again. Fair enough but I don’t want to see that as the norm going forward. We’ll be using rolling subs before we know it.

title: the feelgood feed stories to lift your day
story: Things are tough right now — but the power of community has never been more important or more obvious.In every walk of le, people are coming together to ensure that no one is left to fight coronavirus alone. From neighbours helping each other with simple everyday tasks, right up to the heroes of our NHS on the front line of the fight, we#re standing together to try to help.The Feelgood Feed is here to celebrate this community spirit.Featuring stories from The Evening , Courier, Press  Journal, Evening Express and Sunday Post, we#ll be sharing the most heartwarming, inspirational and even funny ways that people in our part of the world and beyond are helping each other out.DCT Media journalists will always ask the important questions to make sure that the authorities are doing everything they should to help keep us safe. But we also know everyone needs a bit of a boost at times and some reassurance that better days will soon .And, we will be reporting some of the more light-hearted tales unrelated to Covid-, and any national, international or world news we think can put a smile on your face.So our mission is simple: we hope every time you visit The Feelgood Feed, you leave feeling happier than when you arrived.
